column10: Before we begin, please confirm the following
column12: What denomination / network / movement is your church plant affiliated with?
column14: When did the church plant start?
column16: What average attendance (or sized team) did you launch with?
column18: What is your current average attendance?
column20: Which of the following best describes how your church plant launched?
column21: Which of these best describes the geographical area you planted into? Please tick all that apply
column32: What were the traditions of the planting team? Tick all that apply
column41: Where does your church plant meet?
column47: If your church plant/worshipping community employs more than 4 members of staff, please fill in their full-time-equivalence below:
column51: Which group of people is your church plant particularly aimed at/intended for? Please tick all that apply.
column58: To the best of your knowledge, what percentage of your attenders come from non-churched backgrounds?
column59: To the best of your knowledge, what percentage of your attenders come from de-churched backgrounds?
column60: How many first-time faith commitments would you estimate your church has seen since it first started?
column61: Compared to your original aspirations, how successful/unsuccessful has the church plant been at reaching those who are non-churched or de-churched?
column62: In what ways has the church plant been able to engage with those who do not normally go to church?
column63: On a scale from 1 to 100, how different are your church's regular services from those of your sending church?
column64: To what extent has the church plant had to develop new practices in order to reach and disciple people who do not already go to church?
column65: Based on your experiences, what would you say are the key factors that help determine whether a church plant thrives and flourishes?
column68: Based on your experiences, what would you say are the key factors that inhibit a church plant’s growth and development?

column62: Congregational Evangelism Training in engaging neighbours and building natural gospel relationships and friendships in the community rather than putting on lots of events, mixed with continuous mid-week activities (such as Tea and Tots and our seniors coffee morning) which pulls people into the church environment and introduces them to church life and people. Out of this alone many folk have done CE courses and a few have started professing faith in Jesus and have been baptised.
column65: The continuous and faithful preached word of God that takes primacy in the work and life of the church
column66: Prayer from within the body of the launch team from the start for each other and the community
column67: The establishing of faithful, godly elders and leaders to care for the church from the beginning (and if possible the building up of an atmosphere of training within the church family whereby potential future leaders and elders are spotted early and encouraged to use their skills within church life)
column68: Feeling you've "made it" and getting too comfortable with Christian growth... this makes a church fat, but not healthy
column70: Not having a good and right balance between working hard at building up, discipling and preaching to believers - building up the body - and working hard at reaching out to the lost and the local community. If one takes heavy precedence over the other, the imbalance causes big issues in the church... over-egg one or the other you either have a very knowledgeable church with now fervour for evangelism and become insular, or you have a church filled with lots of new people but with no direction and no Spiritual rigour or seriousness.

Creating stepping stones (Engels scale)  for participants to move along (Wellbeing Wednesdays leading into spiritual exploration and focus on Jesus).  Finding and enabling community assets (two of our unchurched mums, one of whom has recently been baptised, are running a new toddlers group connected to our plant).

column62: We run our service on a weekday evening, which means those who take children to Sunday sports clubs can attend. It is an intergenerational church which starts with a meal this mean it serves those who find Sunday services challenging. The meal has been particularly helpful in engaging those who don't normally go to church.
